awd_titl_txt: Stability of Partially Wetting Droplet in Wind
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Lee, Sungyon
Proposal Number: 1605947

The goal of the proposed research is to investigate the behavior of drops that partially wet surfaces under the effect of a cross-wind. The surfaces are imperfect, more like realistic surfaces. Every day applications include the motion of drops on windows, the de-icing of airplanes, chemical process equipment (e.g., in condensers), ink jet printing, and the environment (where rain drops or spray drops move on leave surfaces).

Water droplets that adhere to surfaces then run under wind or gravity are ubiquitous in nature.  Prediction of droplet depinning thresholds is a problem of fundamental importance in fluid mechanics and is relevant to many other engineering problems. While theories exist in the low Reynolds number regime, the problem becomes more complex in the high-Reynolds-number regime of engineering interest due to the unsteadiness associated with boundary layer separation. The overall objective of this proposal is to gain fundamental understanding of the stability limits of a partially-wetting droplet in the high Reynolds number regime, through reduced modeling and state-of-art experimental measurement techniques. The proposed work focuses on the development of a theoretical model that captures the droplet dynamics in the presence of the separated boundary layer flow. The newly developed droplet model incorporates the effects of the external wind in a time-averaged sense to circumvent the difficulties arising from inherent unsteadiness of the flow and droplet surface oscillations. Preliminary results show that the model effectively matches the stability limits of a single droplet on a rough surface in terms of macroscopic properties and is extended to include the effect of solid protuberance. In parallel, additional development of the measurement instrument will be conducted to visualize the unsteady air flow around the droplet and to improve the performance for contact-angle measurements necessary for theoretical validation. The broader impacts of the project include outreach activities for  high school science programs in Texas. The droplet problem is an attractive one for science outreach because droplet depinning is simultaneously familiar yet difficult to understand. This project will use droplets as an example that illustrates how abstractions introduced in high school math and physics can explain phenomena seen in the physical world. The PIs will invite high-school science teachers to work in the lab and to develop curriculum based on the experiment. These teachers will deliver this content to their classes and report on their experiences at a teachers' summit hosted annually at Texas A&M.

por.por_cntn:
Water droplets that adhere to surfaces then run under wind or gravity forcing are ubiquitous in nature. Prediction of droplet depinning thresholds as functions of macroscopic properties such as droplet volume, contact angle hysteresis, surface tension, air flow rate, etc., is a problem of fundamental importance in fluid mechanics and is relevant to aircraft and marine-structure icing, heat-exchanger performance and other engineering problems. While limited theories exist in the low-Reynolds-number regime, the problem becomes more complex in the high-Reynolds-number regime of engineering interest due to the unsteadiness associated with boundary layer separation. Therefore, the overall objective of this proposal is to gain fundamental understanding of the dynamics of a partially-wetting droplet in the unsteady high Reynolds number regime, through reduced mathematical modeling and state-of-art experimental measurement techniques.

We specifically considered the effects of airflows on a water droplet in three distinct configurations. First, we measured the critical wind speeds at which a partially-wetting droplet depins on an inclined surface. Their experimental results revealed that the critical wind speed for depinning decreases with increasing droplet volumes that experience higher body forces. We constructed a reduced mathematical model that rationalizes the experimental observations. Second, we tested the dynamics of a partially-wetting droplet in a wake of the solid protuberance exposed to uniform wind. We uncovered that, depending on the droplet’s distance from the protuberance and the droplet volume, the droplet undergoes three behaviors: depinng downstream (away from the solid), depinning upstream (towards the solid), and splitting. In addition, we showed that the droplet’s motion towards the solid is caused by the low pressure created inside a wake, which we rationalized using a 2D lubrication droplet model. Third, we uncovered the threshold of droplet splitting versus remaining as a single droplet, when an air jet is applied perpendicularly to a partially wetting droplet on the solid surface. The key lies in the droplet’s ability to reach an equilibrium internal pressure before the droplet thickness approaches zero (i.e. splitting). In addition to the physical justification for the threshold criterion, we also numerically computed the evolving droplet shape under a stagnation point flow, by combining the lubrication approximations, potential flow, and boundary layer theory. As part of the proposal, we also refined existing experimental techniques and developed stereoscopic speckle imaging of water droplet interface shapes.

Overall, the intellectual merit of this proposal is to transform understanding of windswept droplets by combining two classical areas of fluid mechanics in a novel way: potential flow/boundary layer theory and droplet dynamics. In addition to the scientific outcomes, the current research has been instrumental in encouraging underrepresented students to pursue academic research beyond undergraduate studies. Furthermore, the approachability of the current research (i.e., a raindrop on a wind shield) has rendered this an ideal project for engaging young students with to consider science and engineering. For instance, we participated in the TAMU College of Engineering E3 summer teacher program which provides an opportunity to high school teachers to conduct research in our lab and to develop hands-on, research-based curricula to bring to their classrooms. The sheer scalability of this unique outreach program allowed us to impact a large number of young students, through our meaningful interactions and collaborations with a small number of STEM teachers. As part of this proposal, we also impacted a largely minority community in rural South Texas through the PLTW outreach trips, as well a highly motivated high school students in the greater Minneapolis area through a summer program called Discover STEM at UMN.
